South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

The first ''at home" of the season of the Khedivial Clob, Alexandria, will take place on Taeeday, 15th January next, at 9.30 p.m.

The scheme for Boulas swing bridge, having been approved by the Public Works Depart- ment, will be put into execation immediately.
Alexandria Municipality.

'At today's meeting of the Manicipal Com- mission the question of the cost of building the consular residence which forms the object of the exchange of land with the French Consulate will come up for discussion.
The Casino Soheme.

It is probable that some decision will be arrived at at this afternoon's meeting of the Alexandria Municipal Commission in reference to the granting of a concession for # casino on the new quay-promenads to Mr. George Ralli.
Coiners Deported.

Caramello Galli, who was sentenced to seven years' penal servitude for coining at H.B.M.'s Supreme Consular Court on Monday, is now incarcerated in Hadra prison, but will be sent to Malta shortly along with two other Maltese prisoners from Cairo who were convicted of a like offence.
Fire at £.T.C.

At Suez, at ten o'clock on Sunday night, & fire broke out on the new premises of the Eastern Telegraph Company. The alarm was immediately given, and the steff, sided by a policeman, fought the flames until the arrival of the fire brigade, which promptly extinguished the fire. Ibrahim Bey Ali, Governor of Suez, and Saghcolagassi de Turris were precent.
An Antique Egyptian Harp

The "Revue Musicale" of Paris announces the receipt from M. G. Maspero of the pho- tograph of a painting found in the Mastsba of Dashont, and preserved in the French Arcbwological Institate of Cairo. This painting ia of a° harpist seated, and dates back to the 12th dynasty (2800 B. C.) The harp is like those preserved in the Louvre Maseom, eight stringed.
Native Woman Kidnapped.

An extraordinary incident occurred a few deys ago at Gheziret el Shakra, in Ghizeh Mondirieh. Some native vagabonds forced an entrance into the house of a native of that village whil he was absent during the night and garrie' off his wife, who was asleep at the time. The woman was naturally terrified, but was ible to call for help. Some neighbours, who awoke on hearing the anusual sounds, went to the woman's assistance, but the kidnappers escaped with their prize after a serious fight, in which the neighbours got the worst of it. The Parquet have opened an inquiry and the police are searching for the kidnapped woman.
Address.

Mr. Clare White, General Secretary of the Royal Army Temperance Association, wi'l deliver as sddrasson "Temperance" at the American Mission on Friday evening, Dccem- ber 2let, at half-past eight o'clock. All are cordially invited to be present. Mr. Clare White has been Seoretary of the R.A.T.A. for twenty-five years, and has done a great work in the Army on behalf of temperance snd right living 99123-2-1

div.head: EGYPT'S GOLD IMPORTS.
div.p: THE SCARCITY OF MONEY,

The recurrence of another period of extra- ordinary stringency in the local money market has set everybody wondering as to what has become of all the money that bas been arriving at Alexandria since the beginning of the season. Over seven million of English sovereigns have come into the country, and yet we are again face to face with a money famine of quite as severe a character as that which raged last October. The large demands which Egypt made at that time for gold from London aroused considerable interest in financial circles in the City, and millions were despatched from England to appease the country's needs. Now Egypt is again calling upon the City for more gold, and this insatiable craving for farther supplies of the precious metal is, asa special telegram from London which we poblished yesterday shows, again giving rise to mach comment at home.

It is to be noted that there have been three well-defined periods daring this season. In October there was a period of-intense strin- gency, followed by a season of comparative relaxation in November, with » reaewal of the stringency during the present month. The original scarcity was due tothe great rosh with which the cotton season started. The relaxation of Isst month was caused by the release cf morey by the fellah. He had paid his taxes and the instalments owing to the Agricultaral Bank with the money he had received for hie cotton and he had also paid the money-lenders and other of his habitual creditors, with whom he always arranges to settle with the coming of the cotton.
This money found its way to the banks, producing the comparative esse prevailing last month.
Bat the felleh still had more stocks of cotton to get rid of, and he continued selling, 80 &
great deal of ths money that had come down

to Alexandria from the interior then had to go back sgain, The fellsh now has no pressing neade, which will induce him to part with his money and is now enjoying the pleasure ot sitting on it for the time being. Thus the existing stringency has arisen. The fellah of courre is only holding his gold temporarily and is waiting his opportunity to buy land, go there is every probability that we shall see a hoge demand for agrisultaral land early next year and a phenomenal boom.
Half « million in hard cash is due at Alexandria from London early next week and
from Constantinople and Naples.
Of course, all this stringency is only a proof of the extraordinary prosperity of the country.

There is no dangerous symptom visible at all in the situation, and the fall in the share markets of Alexandria and Cairo is merely due to the stringency and is not a symptom of any weakness. But on the contrary, ties were hung the flags and shields of the when the morey comes back into circulation again, we shall see a prodigious boem. It is very curious to observe how that

secret of the situation eludes the compre hens on of the City. Speculation there is ripe as to the why and the wherefore of Egypt's craving for gold and many theories are breached, but they all seem to miss the
cardinal point of the whole matter, which is that it is simply and solely due to the prosperity of the country.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive will in all probability spend
the greater part of this week in the neigh- bourhood of Mariont, returning to Cairo on Friday next.

div.head: LEGISLATION COUNCIL.
div.p: We are informed that the members of the
Legislative Council discussed the Estimates for 1907 yesterday. No alteration was proposed, bat the councillors requested the Government to take note of the following suggestions :

1. That the estimates of the Ministry of Education should be increased. In this connec- tion they declared themselves gratified by the increacei expenditure on education, but ex- pressed the hope that still more would be done on its behalt in the fatare.
2. That greater attention should be paid to religious teaching in the Government schools.
3. In their opinion, the Mehkemeh Sbarieh demanded farther reforms, which could only bs carried out by increasad expenditare on these courts.
4. They suggested that the date tax should be removed, as also the toll on ferries.

The decree punishiog persons who refase to assist the operations of the Census Department by fine of L.E 1 or imprisonment was dis cussed. The Council suggested that the im- prisonment should not be inflicted, bit that the fine should be raised to a sum of L.E. 5.

div.head: BACKSHISH.
div.p: The disciplinary council of the Mixed Courts of Alexandria have dismissed two employees of the tribunals and an official belong- ing to the same institution. All these persons were accused of having taken backshish. We sty that the incriminated official is a functionary of high standing and belongs to

The decision of the council has evoked general satisfaction as, although it is considered to be very severe, it is recognised that, if back-bish exists in the very heart of the law- courts, it is necessary to stamp out the evil with the utmost sternness.
The council was composed of Judge Beman, president ; five magistrater, and M. M. A. Salone, the chief greffier.
The two minor employés were "hors cadre."

div.head: STORM IN MEDITERRANEAN.
div.p: SHIPPING DELAYED.
All ships arriving at Alexandria from the Mediterranean daring the past few days have reported experiencing bad weather, and many vessels have consequently been mach delayed.

Considerable anxiety has been felt regarding the Messageries Maritimes 8.8. Equatenr, which was dae at Alexandria yesterday from Marseilles. A telegram received by the local agency states that che only passed the Straits of Messina yesterday morning and will not therefore arrive here till Friday morning.

The Adriatic, too, has bean in as distarbed a state as the Mediterranean. A telegram dispatched from Brindisi last night to the offices of the Fiorio-Rabattino Steamship Com- psny at Alexandria states that that company's 8.8. Bosforo, which should arrive here to- morrow from Venice, haz been forced by stress of weather to lay op in Brindisi harbour. The company will inform the public as to when the Bosforo will be able to resume her voyage and the approximate date of her arrival here.

The Greek §.S. Vassilissa Olga, which ar- rived at Alexandria last night from the Pireos, was thirty hours late owing to the bad weather encountered off Crete. Huge seas were met with, and the gale is reported to have been extraordinarily severe.

div.head: Y. W. C. A.
div.p: SALE OF WORK.

The annual sale of work of the Young Women's Christian Association, Cairo, was held yesterday afternoon and evening at the Grand Continental Hotel, and we have every confidence in voting it a great success, for, though the receipts at the time of writing were unknown, the large attendance and the rapi- dity with which the attractive burdens of the various stalls disappeared guarantee most eatis- factory resulte.

In the absence of Dean Butcher, who, we regret to say, was prevented from attending by a slight indisposition, Major General Bal- lock, C.B., presided. After the singing of the hymn "Now thank we all our God" and the pronouncement of the blessing by the Rev. Thompson Burns, General Bullock, in short introductory speech, expressed his regret at the indisposition of Dean Batcher, and in a ' few well-chosen -words referred to the loss Countess and to the General by the Rev.
present was turned to the stalls. These had been very artistically arranged, and above those which represented nationali-
nation, with suitable mottoes. Weare almost inclined to give place of honour to the Con- naught Houses table,which showed an abund-
' frames, dolls, and many an article which will find its way into Christmas stocking.

patronesses Mesdames Alban, Bullock, Butcher, Boyd Carpenter, Cookson, Hogg, Royle, and Vere Alston, had 8 its motto the well-known message of Nelson to the fleet at the battle of Trafalgar, and nobly was the duty done by stall-holders and purchasers alike.

From England we crossed the border, and stood beneath the motto "Scotland for Ever," admiring a variety of woollen goods, packed as it were amidst the heather of the Soottish moors, and the patronesses of this stall were Lady Blanche Smith, Lady Rogers, Lady Willoocks, Mrs. Graham,Mrs. Milton, and Mrs. Mackenz'e.

"Erin go Bragh" next attacted our attention, and here we found two good old lumps of Irish peat, pen-holders and the like cut out of bog- oak, ornaments of Connemara marble, and a variety of cushions, pincushions, afternoon tea cloths, beautiful drawn-thread linen work and the like, presided over by Mrs. Johnson Pasha, Mrs. Rowlatt, and Mrs. Trevithick.

The American stall, which counted among its patronesses Mrs. Iddiogs, Mrs. Crookshank Pacha, Mrs. Foote, Mrs. Stout, and Mrs. Tuck, specialised in sweets and cakes, and was very well patronised, as was the flower stall.

The Continental stell dealt in fancy work, brio--brac, and many a usefal ornament. "Vive la Fraternité" and "Ahlan wa Sablan" were the mottoes it bore and flags of the German and French nations. The patronesses of this stall were Lady Valda Machell and Miss Farnell.

In the evening the eale was re-opened by the Hon. L.M. Iddings and besides the attractiors of the: stalls an excellent concert was pro- vided, the main item of which was a toy symphony condacted by Miss GertrodeSimpson, an amateur musician of no small note in Cairo. Daring the afternoon the band of the 6th (Inniekilling) Dragoons played a selection of magic under the baton of Mr, Prosser.

div.head: Notes from Suakin.
Farewell Dinners.
div.p: Bimbashi Roasell, R.E., Sudan Railways arrived here on the 7th inet. from Atbara to take over the duties of Agent Sudan Railways, at Soakin from Mr. Hick'ey, who bad been acting agent since the departure of Bimbashi B. Newcombe, R.B.

Geveral dinners were given here last week in honoar of Mr. G. C. Kerr, Senior [nspector Mondirieh Red Sea Provinces, on the occasion of his departare to teke up his new appoint- ment in the Sennar Province. Mr. Kerr him- self gave a dinner on Wednesday night to all the officers, Government cflicials, and principal merchants of the Suakin Mondirieh. Another dinner was given on Thursday by Saghoolaghassi Aly Effendi Ahmed, Deputy Inspector, Soakin Mondirieh, and a third on Friday by Kaimakam Mohamed Bey Ahmed, Commandant of Police, Red Sea Provinces. The band of the 6th Battalion E.A. was in attendance at all the dinners.

Mr. Kerr left here on Saturday, the 8th inet., by express to Khartoum enroute for Sennar. A large nomber of officers, officials, and merchants gathered at Shaatah etation to bid this popular English official "'good-bye."

Another farewell dinner was*given at Suakin on the 10th inst. to Miralai Ibrahim Bey Sirri, commanding 6th Battalion,,E.A., stationed here, who is leaving to-day for Egypt by the Khedivial mail steamer Kosseir. This officer is retiring on pension after 85 years' service. The dinner was given by the officers of the batta- lion and the battalion band was in attendance. The new commanding offiser has not yet arriv- ed. Miralai Hawker Bey, Governor, Red Sea Provinces, was present at the dinner and gave a speech in Arabio regretting very much the departare of Sirri Bey trom Suakin.
Accident to Englishman.

officer of the 8.8. Dunkeld, on the 9th inst., which resulted in the fracture ofa bone of his right leg. Mr. Hoghes was standing onthe ship's deck near No. 1 hold at the time attending tothe discharge of cement. He was giving orders to some natives when the winchman, thinking that he told him to "let go," let the load of about one ton, which was slang up, fall at once, and it dropped on the top of Mr, Hughes' leg, which was resting on a beam. He was removed to the civil hospital on Quarantine Island, and the Darkeld, which is almost ready to sai!, will have to leave him behind.

div.head: SERVIA AND EGYPT.
div.p: The Servian Government is very desirous of opening up commercial relations with Egypt. For the past seven weeks considersb!e imports of fine cattle from Servia have arrived at Alexandria. The cattle are brooght down from Nisch to Salonica and embarked on Greek steamers for Alexandrie.

Servia is a great cattle breading country, and can export £0,000 head of cattle year. There is no cattle plague and the quality of the beef is excellent. Ose of the staple industries of Servia is pig-breading, but unfortanately these | animals are not suited to the Egyptian market. The reason is that the demand here is for small pigs of from thirty to forty kilos in weight, bot the Servian breed is of enormous size and the pige' average weight is over a handred kilos.
It is probable that sheep will also soon be sent here from Servis. The Servian sheep are very fine, and far superior to the animals we receive trom Asia Minor and Syria.

div.head: CONFERENCE SPELTERINI.
div.p: Une admirable représentation a été donnée hier au New Khédiviel Hétel par le capitaine Spelterini devant un cercle restreint mais choisi de dames et de messieurs sppartenant & la meilleare société d'Alexandrie. La per- fection et Ja netteté des projections lamineuses a émerveillé les spectateurs.et excité an plus haut degré lear inté.¢t, Les instantanés des glaciers, des crevasses profondes, qui n'ont probablement jamais été vaes des tonristes les plas intrépides, les vallées, les lacs et les rividres, yvaes & vol d'oisean, les séries de jnneges i-variés, photogrsphiés & des hanteurs différentes, formaient un ensemble. dont tous ont gardé la plus vive et ls plas ineffscable impression. Les merveilles des Alpes retraoées pat ls fidélité des épreaves photographiques ne feavent étre déorites et doivent étre vues pour e'en faireunsidée.Les panoramasdesvilles Suisses(Zarich,St Gall, Bale, Lucerne)et les psy- sages si intéressante qui les accompagnent sont d'an fini et d'ane netteté incomparables. La pos- siesi péné:rante des grandesmontagnes suisses, le Mont Rose,!e Cerviu,le Mettelhorn,le groupe do Miechabel avec les noages environnants, Ia trilogie de 1' Biger, do Ménch et de Ia Yungfrau, tout est rendo avec une perfection quis enlevé l'admiration de toute I'assistance. Les vues des Pyramides, da Caire, des tom- beaux des califes, prises en ballon, sont auesi d'un intérét palpitant. , , :

Nous espérons q7e le capitaine Spelterini pe s'en tiendra pas & cette soirée unique. Selon les journaox d'Europe, il s'est vo obligé, par le snocts éoorme de ses projections scientifiques, & donner on grand nombre de repréeentations partiouliérement & Berlin, ch ily en sen 35 conséoutives au théatre Urania.
Nous ne ponvons donc que souhsiter que
rer les projections qn'il a faites hier soir, devant le: yeux émerveillés des hdtes at des invités da New Khedivial Hotel.

div.head: MLLE BRANDES IN CAIRO.
"L'ESPIONNE."
div.p: L'Espionpe" shows a different side of, or better, throws a different 'ight through which to see Mlle Brandès' acting.

It does not give enough ; but what we get is interesting. I think it would have been still more so, in a more tense atmosphere, with a faller house. For last night's was a wretobed house, a Georges Obnet house, mildly applanding a denonciation Dow and again. They qaite missed that most charming passage : the fortone telling by orange pips-aryan frustrated by three pips in watered orangepolpand I am sure they thought little enough of the clever passage where Dora receives ber genuine offer from André.

Mlle Brandes, as Dora, is at first the young girl of doubtfal enough bringing-ap, Paraguay presidencies, semi-conscious spying, a orowd of men and women whose intentions and ways are far from trustworthy, bills, poverty, shifte, everything to which honourable marriage is 80overwhelming an antidote. Her relief, how ever, is rather at the freedom from that world which bas worried but never tainted her : apd her fary at being suspected by her hasband of spying is of a piece with her whole character, as is indeed her easy forgiveness of him at the end. It was so impossible : be must have bad a fit of madness: she is the more farious in that the accusation never really comes home to her, is not within her sphere. For all this Mile Brandes was more than excellent: she held the note the whole time, and was | ultra-convincing, and natural to perfection. | The play gave some soope to two or three of

the others. Of course, it is onsatisfactory, melodramatio, savoaring faintly of Pearson's Magazine" and Court spies (M. Sardoa woold rise op and slay me, it be read that periodical!). Bat it is clever, not too complioated, and put together with the light, sore hard of a craftsman. Denunciations, the stolen draft, the German Baron, the scented gloves and letters, the "Sourcière" -all is good ; the Buspicion is not too heavily loaded. That sourcière soone was delightfully done by M.] Alerme. I like M. Alerme more and more every time I see him : he is so datural, and thoroughly effective in every point. Per. sonally I prefer him to Rougeelle, Hell, or Araad (uf Mme Hading's troupe) or any of the others with Mlle Brandès - a most attractive actor. Mr. Hall is good, but very conventional. Mr. Rousselle was more in his element and showed much reserved power and passion. Mlle. Marcilly-Marie Maroillybut they are all Maries, for all the world like the Queen of Soots' ladies in waiting ! Marie Fapre, Marie Kalff (who was good too). Mle. Marcilly is above the average'; she has a good
voice and madrer, and very fine eyes, and Bindeed appearance in general; and she uses - all this to the best effect in bor part. She has
a part to herself in a short play to-night, and she should be worth seeing. It must be very bard to escape from convention in the usual full-sized play, with a Brandès, or Hading, or
Bartet above one all the time. A f The remaining programme is "Amoureuse" fand "Le Cæor a 888 raisons" (the short piece
I mentioned) to-night (Tuesday). "L98 Tonailles" Wednesday, and "La Rafale," a great play, on Thursday to complete the series.
People should go at least to one or other of 8these. Mlle. Brandès is so well worth seeing.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL OPERA HOUSE.
div.p: "RIGOLETTO"

On the whole, 'Rigoletto" was a success. The orchestra had improved, the chorus i little to de, and M. Mezy, except for a few moments in the 8rd act, was in gocd voice: his declamation and acting were admi' and he made no attempt to play to the gallery. Gilds (Mile Charpentier) left 'a very pleasant impression. She was jost a little nervous at the start, bat gave "Caro nome" with the ut- most charm and delicacy, and in the fourth act she was admirable. M. Fontsiné was i good form ; his acting perhaps a little wee by comparison with the others. He sang "La donna e mobile" well—the aris bas been murdered often encugh at the Khedivial Opera—and in the qoatuor in the fourth act was heard to great advantage. Sparafacile was less sonorous than we could have wiéhed. Mume Chaix-Bonheur made an admirable Mad- dalena. Most of the Maddalenas we have heard in "Rigoletto" preserved a decorum and repose of manner that could never have attracted the festive Duke of Mantua. Mme Chaix-Bonhear acted up to the part and sang delightfally.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Among the passengers who arrived by the Hohenzollern yesterday were Prince Said , Halim, Admiral and Mrs. Stevens, Vicomte. d'Hautpoal, Comtesse Henrietta Stecks, Sir Hugh Smiley, Bart., Sir Alexander Baird, and Mrs. E.W.P. Poster.

The latest arrivals at the Savoy Hotel in. clude the Earl of Rosslyn, England, Mr. and Mr. G. Low Harriman, Miss Harriman, New York, Baron de. Morogues, Paris, Miss Dacbon Wipcaster, England, M and Mme Artbor Spitzer, Paris, Mrs. C. G. Rodgers, Kentucky, Mrs. Lovell, Kentucky, Mr. C. A. Samoals, London, Mrs. Ellen Slidell, Mme Saunders, M. Quentin and M. Tot, Paris.

Lord Edward Cecil entertained a party at the Savoy Restaurant yesterday evening. The guests iBoluded Mr. and Mrs. Kershaw and Mr. Barton. Mr. Gatmann entertained M. Laon and M. André Saares. Mr. and Mrs. Fowler bad a party of four. The ladies'band played during and after dinner and was much appreciated.

Sir Gilbert and Lady Parker are to spend Christmas in Cairo. Sir Gilbert Parker, who was elected Member of Parliament for Gravesend in the interests of the Conservative party in 1900, was one of comparatively few who did not fall a victim to that disastrous wave of Liberal hysteria which swept over the country at the beginning of the year, and was returned victorious to represent his old constituency. Sir Gilbert is a son of the late Captain Parker and is of Canadian birth, first seeing light in Toronto. He was edocated at Trinity College, Toronto, and from there want to Australia, where he gained fame at an early age as a journalist, being askoriste-editor of the "Sydney Morning Herald." He has always been a great traveller and has many an inte. resting tale to tell about his journeyings among the South Sea Islands. His acquaintance with the East is also considerable, and he has been in most parts of Earope, while his mothercountry, Capada, bas provided him with mary an interesting place of sojourn.

Those who koon Sir Gilbert as an author are not content with one reading of bis works. His "Lover's Diary" is one of the best collections of modern-day verse, and his plays, among which the chief are an adaptation of

Faust," "The Vendetta," "Seats of the Mighty," and "No Defence," show great strength of character and literary ability. His stories and novels are many and withoat exception well worthy of perasal. Perhaps the best known of these, to quote bat a few, are" Donovan Pasha," "The Right of Way," History of Old Quebec," "The Trespasser," The Trail of the Sword," and "The Seats of the Mighty." Sir Gilbert is Hon. Colonel of the Ist Kent Volunteer Artillery. Lady Parker is an American, being the daughter of Mr. Ashley Van Tipe, of New York.
Jadge Cator is returning to Constantinop'e to-day by the Khedivial steamer.
We regret to hear that Dr. Grenfell, the famous Egyptologist, has arrived at Cairo ih a state of health that has caused great anxiety to his friends..

M. Sootidis, the Hellenic Consal General at Alexandria, accompanied by M. Theodoro, chief (consalar interpreter, Møltres Ronssos and Camtas, the legal representatives of the widow of the late M. Pericles Glymenopoulo, and M. John Chiui, the stepson of the deceased gentleman, yesterday went to the Alexandria residence of M. G'ymenoponlo in the Street of the Fatimites and began to make an inventory of all the contents of the house, Afterwards they proceeded to the offiora occupied by the deceased in Old Bourse-street, where two hours were spent in taking another inventory.

Madame Veave P. Glymenopoulo and family take this opportanity of thanking profoundly all those who were kind enough to fend wreaths, flowers, letters and telegrams of condolence on the occasion of the sad death of the late M. Periclis Glymenopou'o.
Dr. Dimitriadis, of Alexandria, has been appointed Norwegian delegats on the Quaranod tine Board
Hassan Effendi Hilmi has been appointed 8 secretary to the Emir El Hag.

div.head:
IMPERIAL PARLIAMENT.
THE EDUCATION QUESTION.
REPORTED COMPROMISE.

div.p: House or Commons. — The. Lords' amend- ments to the Trades Disputes Bill have been rejected unanimously.
The resolution approving the grant of Constitutions to the 'Transvaal and Orange River Colonies was passed unanimounsly.

House of Lords—Lord Lansdowne de- clared that the message from the House of Commons on the Edacation Question was cart and contemptuous and demanded material concessions. Lord Crewe said that while the framework of the Bill must not be altered, the Government was willing to make substantial concessions. (Reuter)
It is understood that a compromise on the
education question has been completed. (Reuter)

div.head:
ITALIAN FOREIGN POLICY.
TRIPLE ALLIANCE AS BASIS.

div.p: Signor Tittoni, in a great speech on foréign affairs in the Chamber of Deputies, declared - the adhesion of Italy 'to the Tiriple Alliance : he denied that it fettered her independence. He discussed exhaustively Anglo-German relations and the possibility of conflicts ; he pointed out that Italy and Austria had a supreme interest in promoting the movement towards an Anglo-German rapprochement, which, he considered, had made progress since last year. (Reuter)

div.head:
CHANNEL TUNNEL.
BILL DEPOSITED IN PARLIAMENT.

div.p: A Bill has been deposited in Parliament to' incorporate a Channel Tunnel Company. It is estimated that the cost of the tunnel will be £16,000,000. (Reuter)
'The Crown Prince publicly announced that he has always been and would be in favour of reforms for the-welfare-of the people. (R.)

div.head: THE PROBLEM OF EGYPT.
div.p: The following is the conclusion of the article by Mr. Robertson, M.P., in the "Twentieth
Century Quarterly"

That some revision of method is needed in Egypt has been quite recently urged is very different quarters. The editor or proprietor of "Al Mokattam" of Cairo, & Syriac Christian, a supporter of the English control, and a defen- der of the Deniahwai executions, combines with all there Conservative qualifications an opinion that the British official class is wanting in sympathy with all forms of non-British life Jin Egypt. To the same effect writes a contri- bator of the Paris ' Temp:," who has apparently little sympathy with the Egyptian Nation: lists as such. The criticism is in fact identical with that passed by Sir Philip Lely on the Indian Civil Service in his interesting little book ; and I have heard both verdicts acqui- enced in alike by Anglo-Indians 'and Anglo: Egyptians. It is in fact the translation into descriptive form of the ordinary tone of unaf- fected Englishnen in regard to the subject races generally. Sir Philip Lely, the last man to be accused of lack of belief in the Empire, appeals to the Indian bureaucracy generally to make, so to speak, a change of heart, and become in future more sympathetic, if they would keep the goodwill of the Indian peoples. He would, I believe, offer the 'same counsel as regards Egypt. Bat while I concur respectfully in his estimate-of the position, I do not pro pose to echo his. counsel. What would be the use? No bureaucracy in the world, no political party, no class or caste; ever did or ' ever 'will transmute its, temper on a mere moral appeal. Sympathy is not.to be evolved by: -whole| class at request. If we are agreed that in a given governmental system more sympathy is needed, there is only one 'way to elicit it. Conditions must be set up which shall be more favourable than the existing conditions to the development of sympathy between -rulers and ruled; and such a change can be wrought only by way of political institutions on the one hand, and diffa- sion of cultare on the other. It is mattér off political adjastment. To say, as.some do, that) "machinery" will not avail in such accuse, is to pronounce the problem iasolable; sad those who have no solution to offer are not entitled tobar any attempt to find one. In reality, "machinery" makes. nearly all the difference| between contented and discontented countries, between Russia and Britain, between Ireland and Scotland, between Poland and Brittany. And change in machinery will affect the spirit of Indian amid Egyptian life a3 it doss that of any other races. As Lord Milaer pat it oon- cerning the téfurm in the Egyptian Civil Service:—"Here,: as elsewhere, a change of system was the first condition of @ change o ohiaracter. Treat the Effendi like man; le him understand that you expect from him obedience, but not servility, that » reasonable objection properly urged will not be resented, and that, if he does his duty, his rights are seoure—and you will be able to get plenty o good work out of him." It is the same autho- rity who speaks of "the simplest ideas o honesty, hamanity, and justice, to the valuo| of which Egyptians are jast as mach alive ag anybody else.

I am here urging the fulfilment of a pro- fessedly accepted principle, not discussing details; and I shall therefore not attempt at thie stage to indicate precisely all the measures that are reqaired. Suffive it to say that they lie in the direction' prescribed by Lord Dafferinand professedly acquiesced in by Lord Milner. There is'n0 need to establish avy new theory of Egyptian haman natare and of imperial method. Lord. Milver 'may be held to typify the professed faith of British official- dom in regard to Egyptian policy: and his admissions sre an ample basis for the ples here pat. Let as grant freely his main stipala- tion ; for the evolation of Egypt toa capacity for self government there is needed "time, time time." The trouble is that this principle is alternat;'y used asa ples for patieace and an excuse for impatience, it not by the same officials, at least ander the same system. When Orientals show themselvas slow to assi- wilate acientific European methods, they are hastily pronounced incapable of improvement. When it is proposed to widen in aoy degree their liberties we are vehemently warned against haste. If we will but remember how slow has been the rate of Eiropean im- provement.in past ages, we shall all agree on the need for deliberation. Bat an alien authority in a position of control, as in Egypt, must at least show that it is bent on doing something in the direction of progress, if it is to avert those very manifestations of discontent of which we have been taking note. In a self-governing country, demands for change, or indictments of the Government, do not pass for "sedition." It is precisely this circumstance that marks off a free from a subordinate community. In England, « perfect tempest of denanciation may befall a Govern- ment without implying any instability in the constitation. In Egypt a far slighter stress of dissatisfaction necessarily figares as "anti- British faeling." It behaves the British control, then, i fit would modify that feeling, to show that of its own accord it is concerned to move, however slowly, in the direction of that ulti- mate self-goverament of Egypt which has been the professed ideal of our stateamn. All that Lord Milner ventures to arge against Lord Dafferin's doctrine is that it did not clearly enough indicate the neei for time. So be it. Bat the time required is tims to move in, not tostand still io. And what movement has been made in the fourteen i Milner wrote? As soon as we come to tests, we face the question of education. If the Egyptian people are ever to be fitted for self-government, they mast first be educated. And herein lies the great fault of our rale over subject races, that it is obstinate'y backward in giving them sshooliag. Sir Philip Lely tells tha: there mast ere long bs a systematic development of popalar eiacation in' India; bat it ie still to come. And in Ezypt it lags n less signifi cantly. In 1892 Lord Miloer, excasiag ths small public provision msde for echo rling in Egypt, wrote that—

"People mast live before they oan be taugh*. Famine is worse than ignorance. What the Egyptian Government had to fizbt for io the early years of the occapation was the very existence of the people. Essential as edacation is, the provision of edacation is not such 8 primary daty of Government as the defence of pérson and property, the maintenance of jastice, or, in a country likeBgypt,...the careful preservation of those works upon which life dependr....And even now & great crowd of scholars is not the thing to aim at, bt rather the thorongh training of a limited pamber. The Government is still far from being in & position to offer » decent education to the majority ot the inhabitants. It has not got a sufficient nomber of properly trained masters evan fur the 6,800 'scholars of its existing Primary and Secondary Sobools. has yet...to educate the men who are destined to fill the Government Service. When these urgent needs have been supplied, it will be time enough to think of general public instruction." Here 'we have 'several separate and ill: vonnedted "pleas fot abstention. from edaca- tional-advance. The first is that "the very 'existence of the people" had been at stake. Yet in. the same book, 'Lord Milner had 'affirmed that "if there is one thing 'sbsolute'y -eortain, it' if thatthe great majority of" the Egyptian nation, and especially the pessantry, have benefited enormously by onr presence in public works, Lord Milner 'gain abd again| testifies thatc"the' iahabitants of 'thes Ni Valley ate the most easity governed people in| the'world: to govern sach s rave is, unde ordinary ciréumstances, a simple task." And| already in 1892, by the sve testimony, the entire machinery of public works had been im proved as "enormously" as the condition of thi fellaheen. Looking for th explanation of sach an ill} defended couree, we find a principal clue giv by a safficiently impartial investigator, writin, in thé satde year with Lord Miloer :— "Wher Téwfk became Khedive, remodelli:-g the' public schools was one of the object dearest to his heart; and he gladly assente to auy'saggestion from his miuisters which ® designed to-extend education and to increas the efficiency of the exis'ing system. The su allocated to these schools, with his entic approval, amounted to £103,000 in 1833. "In that yeae the claims preferred by th precedence over the claims of tha Egyptia: children, and the sam of £35,000 was taken| Ii from the service of ths schoo's and devoted to} paying the exorbitant interest on the pabli debt... . The population of Scotland is aboat ha'f that of Bgypt. In Scotland th Imperial (grant for edacational purposes i £70°,000, the som actaally 'expended being] much larger... . Yet those who thonght they were treating Egypt fairly considered]} £66,838 a year to be safficient for the Depart ment of'Edacation. ... Following the evil preceient thet was then set, the Depsrtment of Finance his contiaued to be as niggard'y as it dared in moeting the just demands ff the Department of Eiacation... Nearly ten years have elspsed since the grant was £103,000." Doubtless it can be pleaded that the Cn- vention of London in 1885 directed the curtailment of expenditure on edacation ; bat if the British control can make no' better defence than that, it is thas paralysed where it ought to be most active, what is its "final claim on Egyptian gratitade? And what evidence is there that the British control is any more zealous for education than the representatives of the European bondholders in general? The latest statistics of Egyptian illiteracy, as offisially supplied to me, parport to be extracted from the general censas of 1897, and are as follows ;— Mare. Femare Toran. Sedentary Egyptian population above the age of seven years (1.¢. ex- cluding Beduin and non- Egyptians) ... ... ... 3,462,817 3,418,827 6,881,744 Ditto, able to read and write, 2.0.1. see vee 389,407 10,269 399,676

Percentage literate... ll perc. 3/10 perc: § perc. It is doubtful whether even these figares do not over-estimate the literacy of the native population, especially as regards the women. But, taken as they stand, they beggar comment. Ae they are offisially given, it is to be inferred that no serious improvement has taken place in the pastten years. Egypt, that is to say, is being kept in a state of abject illiteracy as regards the great mass of' the people, though it is not dispated that they sre eager for the schooling of theit children, and that the children make eager and docile pupils. Natu- rally, what Lord Milner pute as the clearly right course—the directing of all edacational expenditare to the preparation of a subordinate official class—is regarded by some at least of the "nationalist" party as their worst grievance. If a nation is to be fitted for self-government, it is by leavening the mass with kaowledge, by evoking in some degree the mental faculties of all, not by msanafacturing bureaucrats, native or other. From the steadfast pursuit of the latter policy, what is naturally to be inter- red save that the British control is of the mind of the old Khedivé Said : "Why open the eyes of the people? They will only be more difficult to rule!"

Lord Cromer, in his last report, tells us that "it-has even been insinuated that thé British advisers of the Government, though they are not unwilling to teach the tellaheen to read and write, and to encourages industrial schools with a view to educating craftsmen, delibe- rately discourage anything approaching to higher education, as they are unwilling that any steps should be taken calculated to fit the Egyptiens gradually to dispense with European assistance in the government of the country. This peculiar indictment he meets as follows : Some seventy 'years' ago 'Lord Macanlay dealt with s somewhat aualogous argument. "Are we," he said, "to keep the people of India ignorant in order that we may keep their submissive?' He' réplied to the question with an indignant negative. "Governments," he said, like men, "may' bay existence too dear. Propter vitam vivendi perdere causas is a despicable policy both in 'individuals and in States." I can add nothing to what *'Lord Macaulay said in reply to this unworthy insinuation, which is belied by the facts, now only in Egypt,' bat in 'every country where 'the British flag Gies or British influence is para- mount. There is here such an entire misconception of the nature of Macaulay's argument that one is moved to ask 'whether "Lord Cromer has accurately gathered thé criticism to which he himself is replying: Macaulay was not meeting g charge' against the "British Government of withholding education "from any class of the inhabitants of India. 'He' was doing the very reverse. He-was-repeliing—an English demand' that no opportanities should be given 'to In- dians which should tend to help them towards independence ; and he. was justifying the pro- vision in the Bill of 1833 "that no native of our Indian Empire shall, by reason of his oolbur, his descent, or his religion, be incapable of holding 'offics." Macaalay declared that, he should always be 'proud of having helped to franie the Bill containing that clause. As 6 matter of fact, its Osténsible purpose hss never been thoroughly soted on to this day. But still less has the British Government in India ever attempted to educate the masa pf the people by way of*fitting them for self govern- ment. It is difficult, therefore, to follow. Lord Cromer's reasoning. He can certainly 'claim that his 4dministration has put @ stop to feeless higher education, which had become in' effect! a privilege of the upper classes instead of an aid tothe poor. In this connexion, he notes that Ismail's schools were set up solely in order| to train functionaries for the public service. As we have seen, Lord' Milner expressly claim: that that is what has been aimed at under the British control. And what is being done tol- tesdh the fellaheen handicrafts, or reading and writing? From 1890 to 1895, Lord Cromer| shows, the total attendance at Government! schools and colleges of all grades has risen from 9,231 to 18,712 ; bat of the added 9,509 only 5,500 attend the Governtext Kauttabs or elementary schools, though 1,478 attend the| "Gostitations for training teachers for Kattabs. There is that nothing like a proportional" in- crease in the schooling of the mass of the people. Finally, Lord Cromer declares that, as formerly, the money cannot be found to do more. "Mr. Danlop in « recent note states as| a very moderate estimate that a sum. of £400,030 is urgently required"; over and above, that is, the present estimated expendi- ture of £276,000. 'I do not doubt," says Lord Cromer, 'the correctness of hie figare, but even}; edncation must yield to the paramount ne- c2ssity of maintaining eqoilibriam. Some while must, I° fear, elapse 'before the Financial Depa-tment will be in a position to grant the whole of this som." No one doubts Lord Cromer's thrift and financial exactitude. Bot ean Lord Cromer wonder if the mora critical spirits in Egypt, seeing only some qaarter of a million per annum speot on their own echools, while three millions and. three .quarters go to European bondholders as iuterest On the Debt, of theprincipal of which Egypt received 20 litt'e, ate imperfectly gratefal fur the blessings of foreign rale ? It is not the business of the onlooker to pre- scribe to the expert the ways and meansof a more plausible adjustment of proportions. Bat it is for the British people to take note that they are collectively responsible for the state of things under notice. It was on behalf of British capitalists that the armed force of Britain was first turned upon Egypt. Britain, further, is now making handsome profit out of the Suez Canal shares which the impecunious Iemail sold, to the farther impoverithment of his doontry. Whatever Egypt may owe to the British, the British owe to Egypt au annual revenue immensely in excess of what the British control enables Egypt to spend on the school- ing of her own population of twelve millions Are they quite satisfied? And if not, can they 'expect the Egyptians to be? Here, surely, is the starting point for the policy which shall vindicate the professions of English statesmen in the past, and so tarn the edge of Egyptian discontent in the future. The situation can be put in a nutshell. A desire for the development of self governing faculty in Egypt bas 'been avowed by the most con- servative of our politicians. Whatever are to be the steps in the process as regards political institutions, education of the people is # primary condition of success. If Egypt can afford any increase in expenditure, she can afford more outlay on schooling, which, rationally directed, will tend to increase native efficiency in all directions.

Mr. Maohe'l, in s memorandom "On Crime in Egypt" appended to Lord Cromer's last. This breeds envy, malice and hatred. "The greater amount of crime in Egypt to-day can be trated directly to these causes." 'This does not quite eqaare with Lord Cromer's own summing 'up. Bat, sopposing it to be sab- stantially trae, what is the nataral comment 4 If » nation shows @ tendency to crime—in particular to crimes of revénge —in time' of econortic improvement, what would be said jio any civilised cotntry to be the proper policy of cortedtion 1 What is being dons ia civilized countries where increase of crime has been noted in larger degree than in Egypt? The answer obtrades itself. The cure for Egyptian morals is the cure for Egyptian politics.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: A change has beeu made in the itinerary of the S.S. Sicilia, which will carry out the remaining reliefs between home stations and Malta, Crete, and Egypt. Tbe trooper will leave Southampton on the 13th February with the 1st Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers on board for Crete, together with various drafts for Malta and Egypt. She will reach Malta on the 22nd, disembark drafts and proceed the same day to Crete, arriving there on the 24th, and disembarking the Inniskillings, and taking on the 2nd Battalion Royal Sussex Regiment. From Crete she will go to Alexandria, and exchange the drafts for invalids and time-expired red, her date of arrival being fixed for the 26th. The Sicilia will leave Alexandria on the 27th, call at Malta and Gibraltar the 2nd and 6th March, and on the 11tb she will anchor in Southampton waters, and disembark the Suseex men for Belfast, where they take the place of the Inniskillings

Major C. W. Wilson, D.S.O., King's Royal Rifle Corps, has taken his retired pay. He spent nearly nineteen years in the Rifle, and was adjutant of the 3rd Battalion during the South African War, including the protracted fighting on the way to Ladysmith, being en gazed at Colenso. Spion Kop. Tagela Heights Vaal Krantz, Pieter's Hill, and the action of Ling': Nek, following the relief, and in the campaign of 1900-01 he saw further service (mentioned in despatches, D.S.O., Queen's medal with five clasps). He was latterly employed at the War Office.

The vacant majority has been filled in the Rifles by the advancement of Captain H.C. Warre, D.S.O., of the 3rd Battalion, Alderebot. Major Warre has been connected with the Rifles since October, 1887, and got his company in January, 1895. He has a five record of service in the field--Hazara expedition, 1891 (medal with clasp); Miranzsi Bxpedition, 1891. (cle&p); operations in the Chitral Relief Force, 1895 (medal with clasp); and the South African War, when he served on the staff of the Ladysmith Relief Force, and subsequent campaign (mentioned in despatches, D.S.O., Queen's medal with five clasps, King's medal with two clasps), and his field service qualified him for staff employment.

after the lengthened sobaltern service of almost pine years. Captain Peel was with the Brigade of Guards in the arvance to the relief of bard pressed Kimberley, sharing in the actions of Belmont, Enslin, Modder River, Magersfontien, Poplar Grove, Driefontien, Vet River, Zand River, the actions near Johannesburg, and Pret ris, and the battle of Diamond Hill, and sandry engagements and minor affairs in the succeeding operations (Queen's medal with six clasps, King's medal with two clasps).

The decision of the Army Council to abolish the appointments of Riding-masters in the cavalry has caused more or less consternation amongst the senior warrant and non-commissioned officers to whom these berths were in the nature of an inducement to remain in a service which is notoriously hard worked. The decision reduces by half the appointments to which intelligent, well conducted soldiers could look forward as an inducement to excel in the profession they had chosen. It will not affect those already holding the appointments, but as their positions fall vacant they will not be replaced, and the training in riding, etc., will devolve on the regimental adjutant.

The shooting of the cruiser Drake, flagship of Rear Admiral Prince Louis of Battenberg, commanding the Second Cruiser Squadron, bag been an eye-opener to the possibilities of long range naval gunnery. A short time ago, a 50 & per cent, 'score at 1,800 yards was looked upon with admiration and envy. What can be said of an 80 per cent, score at a range of four miles, and a smaller target? The gunners of the Drake----which is the swiftest cruiser afloat at their recent battle practice hit the target 105 times out of 138 rounds. Nothing in naval gunnery can approach this marvellous practice, and of course the Drake easily goes to the head of the British Fleet as the straightest shooting ship in it. The skipper of the Drake is Captain Mark E. T Kerr, and the gunnery officer ia Lieutenant Humphrey T. Walwyn.

div.head: VALUABLE EGYPTIAN ANTIQUITIES TO BE SOLD.
div.p: A sale of Egyptian antiquities, dating from the predynastic period, BC. 4400, down to the Greek and Roman epoche, will take place at Messre. Sotheby's on the 19th inst. The collection was formed in Egypt by Mr. R. de Rustaijaell, and is one of the largest ever taken to England by a private collector, and covers practically the whole of Egypt and its history, but principally the period of its finestling art, viz., the eighteenth dynasty. B.O. 1700, which is represented by beautiful pottery, bronzer, figures in wood, and fresco painting. hu

To the late Sudanese campaign belong many trophies of war, such as the standards and "U arms of the fighting emirs, Osman Dignus and me Mahmoud and the praying board of the late Khalifa ; also & number of swords, shields, and coats of mail, dating from the Crusaders' timo and a Saltaba's richly ornamented regalis in silver and amber.

The oldest period, namely, the predynastic, is represented by a large assortment of palæslithic and neolithic flint implements, and some fine stone and clay pottery, and the early dynasties by painted pottery and a seated bronze or silver figure of a king. This unique figure, which is about 10in. high, dates from about B. C. 4000. There are also a number of wil mummies and mummified sacred animals, blue the glazed figurettes, -amulets, beads, papyri, scarabæi, and some verys i fiderGreek pottery I thi and-Roman glass.

div.head: EGYPTIAN YARN MARKETING.
div.p: An interesting reference to the marketing of the Egyptian cotton grown in Sind is made in the "Times of India." It appears that attention was drawn in the Legislative Council to the great disparity between the prices realised by the growers in India and by the "middlemen in England. It was said officially las that this was a matter for the manufacturing capitalist and not for the Government. It appears, however, that the Government has been better than its word, and a considerable quantity of the cotton has been sold by auction under official auspices. The prices realised are described as extremely gratifying. I am ing, being "equivalent to from 8(¼)d. to 9(½)d. 1 per pound in England. The last consignment was sold in England at about 10d., though the price paid in India was only about 5d. per pound." This particular cotton will be consumed by the Abmedabad mills.

div.head: JERUSALEM
div.p: A Jerusalem correspondent writes :- Mr. Haydn Righton gave his second evening concert on Wednesday last (the 12th inst.) at Mr. Hughes' hotel. In spite of the very unfavourable weather there was a good audience; and those who had braved the elements-and the mod-were amply repaid by performance which, for general excellepoe, was equal to any given in the city for some time. Out of 14 numbers eight were instrumental, and in these the conductor was fortunate to have the assistance of Mr. Bayer and M. Völkor (fates). I : Dr. Binsler and Dr. Radoliffe (violins), and m.). Laurent (cornet à piston).
The concert opened with an operation air by Bellini in which MM. Beyer and Volker gave evidence of considerable skill. Dr. Einsler presented a very sympathetic rendering of an

Elégie" by Ernst. M. Laurent, a complete li master of his superb instrument, gave so much 1: pleasure with his "Caprice et Variations" (arban) that he had to repeat part of it ; good cornet soloists are rare, bat M. Ladrant ranked among the best we have heard in London and Paris ; big daet with M. Völker, "Boho," (Köhler) was one of the most pleasing items in the programme. In the second part doel for flats by Mozart was well received. The chief event of the evening was Mr.Righton's rendering of the Sonata Pathétique" (Beethoven) ;L! he bad evidently made a careful study of this exacting work and held his audience completely throughout the fear movements. The other instrumental numbers were a "Romance" and 8 March, both bearing Mr. Righton's signature and in the rendering of which he was ably supported by the five gentlemon named. The vocal part of the programme consisted of two songs, "The Kerry Dance" and "Love's old sweet song"s pleasingly song by Miss Addis, "The Good Shepherd" reverently rendered by Mr. Hghes, the charms of "Annie Laurie" faithfully portrayed by Canon Carnegie Brown, and the three Chafers" and "Massa's in de cold, cold ground." presented by a small choir of male voices.

The concert was given in aid of the funds of St. James' Hostel, the native boarding house for boys attending the boys' school at St. George's. We hear that Mr. Righton proposes to give a Chamber Concert later ia the season.

div.head: MACMILLAN'S COLONIAL LIBRARY
div.p: The latest addition to MacMillan's excellent Colonial Library is Mrs. Herbert A. Watson's new novel "Andrew Goodfellow." It is a tale of 1805 dealing with l-fe at Plymouth during the exciting time of the Napoleonic wars. The story is brightly written and toll of interest.

div.head: DISCOVERY AT CAIRO.
div.p: THE OLD NUBIAN LANGUAGE.

A discovery of great importance for philology and history has just been made in Cairo by the German esvant, Karl Schmidt, a well known authority on Coptic and the early Christian archæology of Upper Egypt. Some insignificant sheets of parchment, supposed to be late Coptio manuscripts of small value, were offered to him for sale. He at once noticed that the language was not Coptic at all, and concluded from the occurrence of the word "Uro," which among the modern Nubians means "King," that the text was written in Nabian. Thir, however, was a great discovery, since Nabian, though still spoken, 'bas long ceased to be a written language. As soon, therefore, as these documents can be fully deciphered, philological science will be the richer by the knowledge of the language spoken by the inhabitants of Nabis before the invasion of the Semitio tribes. A farther consequence is that it will probably now be possible to read thao Inscriptions on a large number of ancient monuments in Egypt, which, op till now, have remained a mystery and these inseriptions will, doubtless, throw light on the history of the earliest Nabian races.

Prof. Schmidt has ascertained already that the two Nabian fragments are translations of Christian works, the first of a collection of extracts from the New Testament, the second to a hymn to the Cross, in which frequent reference is made to St. Paal. Unfortunately, the Greek original of this hyma is not known. Both MSS. date from the eighth century A.D.

div.head: ARABIC TRANSLATOR'S GUIDE.
div.p: Among the books' we have lately received is a copy of the Translator's Guide.* This is a work intended for the use of Arabs who wish to learn English ; and the preface by Prof. Margolioath claims that the student who has mastered the rules on syntax as set forth in it should be safe from the ordinary errors into which foreigners are apt to fall. These rules appear to us to be dealt with in a very able ! way from the translator's point of view. Among them are several' which we have not been before, probably for the reason that they are not set forth in books intended solely for Baglieb papile, however helpful they may prove to foreigners. The section on prepositions should be very useful to those who wish to write English better than "she is spoke." The esme remark applies to the idioms throughout the book. The specimen translations give & good idea of the possībilities of achievements in that direction.

We note that the book shares, in common with most books printed in this country, the fault of a few printer's errors , and would recommend that in any subsequent edition no effort should be spared to eliminate them.
*The Translator's Guide, for use in Egyptian schools. By M. el Sayed, A. Ibrahim, Sheikh A. Shawish, W. H. Stephens, B.A.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie.) Il y a stagnation presque complète d'affaires. On a traité seulement, et encore dans des proportions restreintes, les Ritz Hotels, l'United Egyptian Lands, l'agricole, la National Bank, la Cassa di Sconto, la Delta Land, le Comptoir et le Crédit Franco-Egyptien.
L88 variations de la cote, d'ailleurs pea nombrense8, Bunt en général dans le sens de la baisse. Quelques valeurs sont cependant en reprise.
De oe nombre sont les Markets de 29 à 29/9, les Cotton Mills de 6 à 6/3, l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 38 à 39/3 et la part de fondateur Comptoir de 60 à 60 1/8.
L'Anglo American Nile passe de 5 3/8 ven. deurs à 5 3/8 acheteurs.
En revanche la Building Lands s'effondre de 5 13/16 à 5 3/8.

En baisse également la National Bank de 28 1/16 à 28 1/32, les Tramways d'Alexandrie de 203 à 202 les Privilégiées et de 350 acheteurs # 350 vendeurs les Dividendes, la Salt and Soda de 25 à 24/6, la Cassa di sconto de 261 à 263 l'ancienne et de 259 à 258 la nouvelle, la Banque d'Athènes de 136 à 135 1/2, les Nungovich Hotels de 31 5/8 à 21 1/4, la Nile Land de 17 8/4 à 17 5/R, et l'Union Foncière de 6 1/4-5/16 à 6 1/4 vendeurs.
L'United Egyptian Lands débate & £l vendeurs pour remonter on clotore à £1 1/32 aobeteur. Beaucoup d'affaires à ce prix.
Les Ritz Hotels content 1 9/16 acheteurs.

Ioi nous avons ev, ce matin, an marché en général calme et sans affaires, avec contingation de la tendance à la faiblesse sur la plupart des valeurs. Les actions de la Société d'Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux ont seules donné lisad on courant de transactions, ainsi que les actions des Excelsior Hotels.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National s'est maintenue à 28 1/16-1/8. L'Agrioolo a avancé à 9 1/29/16. La Cassa di sconto a molli à 263. La Daïra s'est alourdie . 17 5/16 et l'Union Foncière à 6 3/16. Les Allotments sont remontés à 3 7/8 et leur part à 142.

Lås notions Entreprise, Immobilières et Travaux, qui ont clôturé hier à 11 3/8, ont débuté à 11 1/2 pour monter graduellement à 1 3/4. 12. 12 1/8 et se consolider en clôture à 12 1/8-1/4. Le nombre des transactions sur ce titre tend à 36 restreindre par euite, paraitil, de la disparition da Alttant, amenée tout naturellement, à ce que nous fait observer on de nos lecteurs : 1°. Par les dépôts de titres effentiés au siège de la Société en vue de l'assemblés extraordinaire da 2 Janvier 1907; 2°. Par le fait qae l'honorable Corporation des Agents do Change collectionne les Botions & l'effet de dénicher le découvert ; 3° Parce que quelques capitalistas ou spéculateurs les collectionnent également dans un ordre d'idées moins platonique; 4° Parce qu'il y a des amateurs de choses rares qui désirent enrichir leur portefeuille de ce titre ; 5o. Parce qne le public veat absolument en avoir. La conclusion rationdelle est que l'objat est appelé forcément à être adjagé au dernier enchérisseur,
La part de fondatear a été traitée entre 99 et 102 poor olótarer à 100. .
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nangovich ont faibli à 21 9/16-5/8, les Egyptian à 9 1/2 et les National à 3 15/16-4. Les Exoelsior ont été reobercbés à 4 7/16-1/2
Parmi les petites valeors, la Delta Land a été ramenés à 4 7/16 1/2 et les New Egyptian 1 31 sh. 3 Les Khedivial Mail ont progressé à 39 sh. et les Salt and Soda à 24 sh. 9.

div.head: His Britannic Majesty's Consulate at
div.p: Alexandria
REGISTRATION 1907.
NOTICE is hereby given that all British subjects residing within the district of this consulate are bound to register themselves during the month of January.
All persons neglecting so to register themselves are liable to fine or imprisonment.
The consulate will be open daily from 10 8.m. till doon for the delivery of registration certificates.
BY ORDER. 29089 6-3

div.head: The Khedivial Mail Steamship and Craving Dock Company, Ltd.
div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that an Extraordinary General Meeti' g of the abovedamed Company will be held at Winchester House, Old Broad Street, London, E.C., on Monday, the 31st day of December, 1906, at 12.35 o'clock in the afternoon, for the purpose of considering, and it deemed advisable, passing the 't allowing Resolution with or without modification.
RESOLUTION.

"That the capital of the Company be increased to £400,000 by the creation of 100,000 Dew Ordinary Shares, and that in lieu of each new shares being offered in the manner provided by Article 13 of the Company's Articles of Association, the Directors be and are hereby authorised and empowered to issue the said new shares opon such'termg, to price, and op Bach conditions as to underwriting, and other Wise, and at soch times, and generally in 'Boch 9 matter as they may deem expedient, and whether in the form of bearer sharer, or registered shares, or partly in one form and partly in the other, provided always that the lo Directors shall give a preferential allotment of gach new shares to the holders of Ordinary | A and Preference Shares of the Company in proportion to their respective boldings."
Should the Resolution be passed by the required majority it will be submitted for confirmation as a Special Resolution to & second Extraordinary General Meeting, which will be subsequently convened.

In the event of a bearer of & Share Warrant desiring to vote at the above-mentioned Meeting, he most on or before the 20th day of December, 1906, deposit such Share Warrant with the Imperial Ottoman Back, Alexandrie, or on or before the 24tb day of December, 1906, with M 388rs. Gyo, Mills, Currie and Co, 67 Lombard Street, London, E.C.
By order of the Board, L HALLIDAY
Secretary Dated this 30th day of November, 1906. No. 72 Bishopsgate Street Within, London, E.C.

div.head: In His Britannic Majesty's Consular
div.p: Court at Cairo.

NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that under the terms of Article 121 of the Ottoman Order in Council of 1899 bis Court will itself administer the Estate of the late Kenneth Lindsay McLean Engineer of Cairo who died intestate at Csiro within the Jurisdiction of this Court on the 21st day of November 1906 ard that all persons having claims on the estate should bend in their claims to this Court before the 15th day of January 1907 on which date this Court will proceed to distribute the Estate having regard only to such claims as have then been presented.
By order H. M. PEPPERCORNE,
Marshal of the Court Cairo, December 12, 1906. 29023-3*-3

div.head: The Alexandria Water Company Ltd. SERVICE D'EAU FILTREE A RAMLEH.
div.p: La Compaguie prie MM. les habitants de Ramleb, qui désirent prendre un abonnement pour la fourniture de l'eau filtrée, de présenter 40 plus tôt leurs demandes par écrit avec
indicarion exacte de la situation de leurs immeubles afin de faciliter l'étude de la canali. tation técessaire.
La Compagnie établira la canalisation dans les rues, les frais, ser ope lor goeur à calcolée à raison de 30 mètres courants par abonnement.

Et si la distance à parcourir pour atteindre les conduites principales était plas grande, la canalisation pourra être posée quand même, pourvu que les abonnés participent dans la 'épense, poor oet excédent dans les propor'ions à convenir.

La fourniture de l'eau filtrée re sera faite qne par compteur etx mêmes conditions et prix que coox en viguear pour la Ville, dont MM. les abonnés pourront prendre connais sance en s'adressant aux bureaux de la Com pagpie.
L'administratenr. Directeur. J. E. CORNISH.

div.head: Municipalite d'Alexandrie
div.p: A VIB
La Municipalité met en adjudication lat fourniture de 14.000 m2 de pierre poor dallage u des Chaussées.
Le cautionnement est fixé à L.E. 560.
Le cahier des charges est dépoé an bare a de la Voirie où il pent être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 b. à midi; los jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 16 Janvier 1907.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour 5 h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention : "Sonmission pour fourniture de pierre pour dallage."

Le cautionnement ou le reça d'ane banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis aéparément au Service de ti la Comptabilité Gévérale avant l'ouvertare des offres et au plus tard le 15 Janvier 1907 lir à midi.
Toate offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur,
Signé: W. P. CHATAWAY. Alexandrie, le 10 Décembre 1996. 29057-32

div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT.
div.p: DISPOSAL OF BUILDING SITES
AT PORT SUDAN.
The Sudan Government will shortly dispose by Tender of about 400 Building Sites at Port Sudan.
The sites will be Leasehold held at Annual se Rents on Building Lease for Eighty Years from 1st January, 1907. Rents will be payable only from date of acceptance of Tender.
The Lease will be Perpetually Renewable at Revised Rents fixed in default of Agreement by P Arbitration at the end of each term of years.
In fixing the revised rents the value of Build-le ings erected by Lessees will Not be regarded a as a ground for Increase of Rent

Example: If a plot is leased for a term of 1s 80 years from 1st January 1907 then on the 1 expiration of that term the Lessee will have a right (subject to observance of his convenant la etc) to obtain a fresh lease for a further period of 80 years at a revised rent, and so on in perpetuity. The revised rent will be calcul- ê ated on the value the site would bear if it were vacant building lands.
Offers are invited of Premiums for the Pur-le chase of the above mentioned leasehold sites.
All offers must be made by Tender, on the forms issued by the Sudan Government, and a must be received at Khartoum not later than 1st January 1907.

Particulars of the sites offered, Plan of the Town, Conditions of Tender and Sale, Form of Tender, specimen Form of Lease, etc., will on and after October 1st 1906 be open to inspection at the following places during the usual business hours : Khartoum : *Office of Director of Agricul
ture and Lands (T) and Office of Governor
of Khartoum Province. Cairo : *Office of Sudan Agent (T). Port Sudan: Office of Inspector (Govern.
ment Office) (T). Suakin : Office of Governor of Red Sea
Province. El Damer : Office of Governor of Berber
Province. Atbara : Office of Director of Railways. Alexandria : Office of Mr. Macpherson Grant. Port Said: Office of Dixon Bey, War Office
Representative London: *Office of Col. Western, Broadway!
Chambers, Westminster, and the Sudan
Court, Imperial Institute. Suez : Office of Capt. Falconer, War Office

Representative. For the convenience of intending purchasers the Conditions of Tender and Sale have been translated into Arabic and French and copies of the translations into either language will be obtainable after 1st October 1906 on payment of 5 P.T. per copy at the Offices in the above list which are distinguished by a capital T.
Further information will be obtainable after the publication of the above-mentioned documents on application in writing to The Direc. tor of Agriculture and Lands, Khartoum.
*Copies of the Doouments will be obtainable after 1st October 1906 on payment of 5 P.T. or 1 Shilling per copy at the Offices marked with an asterisk.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: (L'EGYPTIAN GAZETTE" Le Sopplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paralt chaque Samedi a midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichiep. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de noton, et du marobé des valeurs ; les derpières statistiqaes jusqu'a la veille de sa publiGation : des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêobes officielles envoyées a la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc. ete
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte oogte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste ; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en BUB.

div.head: GOUVERNEMENT DU SOUDAN
div.p: Concessions de Terrains & Batir
a Port-Soudan
Le Gouvernement du Soudan va prochaine ment disposer, par voie d'adjudication d'environ 400 parcelles de terrains a batir à PortSoudan.

Les dites parcelles seront données a bail emphytéotique, pour une durée de 80 années & partir du ler Janvier 1907, moyennant loyer annuel, & charge pour le locataire de bâtir. Le loyer ne sera payable qu'à partir de la date de l'acceptation de l'offre.
Les baux seront renouvelables à perpétuité moyennant un loger variable fixé la fin de chaque terme, soit d'accord, soit pár arbitrage.
En fixant le nouveau loyer, la valeur des bâtiments élevés par le locataire ne sera pas considérée comme un motif d'augmentation de loyer.

EXEMPLE: Si une parcelle de terrain est louée pour une durée de 80 années à prtir du ! ler Janvier 1907. Dans ce cas, a l'exapiration de ce délai, le locataire aura un droit (* conditiond'observer les conditions du bail) d'obtenir un nouveau bail pour une nouvelle période de 80 années, moyennant un loyer modifié, et ainsi 12 a perpétuité.
Le loyer modifié sera calculé sur la valeur du terrain, s'il était libre de construction.

Des offres sont demandées pour les baux emphytéotiques dont s'agit ; ces offres devront mentionner la prime que le soumissionaire est disposé a payer au comptant en sus des loyers annuels établis pour chacun des lots. La dite a prime devra être payée en un seul versement air la 'signature du contrat de bail.
Toutes offres doivent être faites par soumission, sur les formules dressées par le Gouvernement du Soudan, et doivent êtr Khartoum avant le ler Janvier 1907.

Le détail des terrains offerts, le plan de la fa ville, les conditions de l'adjudication et de la w concession, la formule de soumission, spécifica- n tion du bail, seront a la disposition du Public & partir du ler Octobre 1906, aux lieux ci-aprè indiqués, durant les heures de bureau.
Khartoum*-Bureau du Directeur de l'A. griculture et des Terrains (T) et bureau du! Gouverneur de la Province de Khartoum.
Le Caire* - Bureau de l'agent du Gouverne-- ment du Soudan
Port-Soudan* _Bureau de l'Inspecteur (Bureau du Gouvernement (T).
Souakim-Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province et de la Mer Rouge.
Wadi-Halfa-Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Halfa.
El-Damer-Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Berber.
Atbara-Bureau du Directeur du Chemin de Fer.
Alexandrie –Bureau de Mr. Macpherson Grant.
Port-Saïd- Bureau de F. Dixon bey, Représentant du Ministère de la Guerre.
Londres --Bureau du Colonel Western, Broadway Chambers, Westminster et le Soudan Court, Imperial Institute.
Suez- Bureau du Capitaine Falconer, Représentant du Ministère de la Guerre.

Pour la commodité des acheteurs éventuels les conditions d'adjudication et de concession ont été traduites en arabe et en français et des copies de ces traductions, dans les deux langues, peuvent être obtenues & partir du ler Octobre 1906, moyennant payement de d P.T. 5 par copie, aux bureaux mentionnés duns in la liste ci-dessus, qui sont suivis d'une lectre a majuscule T.

Des informations supplémentaires peuvent li être obtenues après publications des documents S ci-dessus mentionnés, moyennant demande 2 écrite adressée au Directeur de l'Agricultures et des Terrains, à Khartoum.
Aux bureaux marqués d'uno astérisque, copies des documents pourront être obtenues à partir du 1 Ootwbre 1906 moyennant payement de P.T. 5 ou u shelling par copie.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907
